clean_story:
Sunlight catchers. Nature’s food factories.

The word "leaf" comes from Old English lēaf, meaning the green, flat part of a plant.

Most see leaves as just green decorations on trees.
But they’re tiny solar panels.
Inside, cells packed with chlorophyll—a green pigment—absorb sunlight.
Like a kitchen mixing ingredients, leaves combine sunlight, water, and CO₂ to make sugar (photosynthesis).
A single oak leaf can produce enough oxygen in a day for 10 people to breathe for an hour.

Some leaves adapt in extreme ways.
Cacti have spines instead of leaves to save water.
Sundew plants grow sticky leaves to trap insects for nutrients.
Even colors change: red maple leaves signal "stop eating me" to pests.

Leaves also talk—chemically.
When attacked, they release scents warning nearby plants to defend themselves.
A study found willow trees boosted their chemical defenses after "hearing" a neighbor’s distress signal.

Three related subjects are plant communication, desert survival tricks, and how colors fool predators.
